title: Willie Colón: A Music Star Who Made Salsa Popular
summary: Willie Colón was a famous musician who played the trombone and helped create salsa music. He was born in New York to parents from Puerto Rico and started his career when he was young. Willie made many popular songs like 'El Malo' and 'Oh, Qué Será' that people still love today. He used his music to tell stories about being Puerto Rican in America, mixing sounds from jazz and Caribbean music. Sadly, he passed away at age 75, surrounded by his family. His manager said Willie's music was not just for fun—it helped people feel proud of their culture and identity. He was called an architect of the New York sound because he brought salsa to big stages and made it important. Even today, stars like Bad Bunny mention him in songs to honor his legacy.

background_read: Willie Colón was a musician born in 1950 in New York to Puerto Rican parents. He learned Spanish from his grandmother and grew up listening to Caribbean music. In the 1960s, he started making salsa music by mixing different sounds like jazz and mambo. His songs often talked about the experiences of Puerto Ricans living in America, helping people feel connected to their culture. He became very famous and won awards, and even after his death, other artists like Bad Bunny remember him in their music.
